awd_abstract_narration: The University of Washington (UW) proposes an extension for the Alliance for Access to Computing Careers (AccessComputing). AccessComputing engages individuals with disabilities as well as those who support, serve, guide, educate, and employ them in transformational efforts to make the computing disciplines more welcoming and accessible to individuals with disabilities, including post-9/11 veterans. AccessComputing, a combined effort of UW's Department of Computer Science and Engineering and  DO-IT (Disabilities, Opportunities, Internetworking, and Technology) Center, in partnership with diverse set of postsecondary institutions, BPC Alliances, and computing organizations. The Alliance aims to (1) increase the capacity of postsecondary institutions, precollege educators, BPC Alliances, and industry to fully include individuals with disabilities in computing fields; (2) provide direct services to individuals using evidence-based practices that support those individuals as they move through critical junctures on the way to computing careers; (3)  build synergistic and lasting relationships among stakeholders to promote systemic changes toward inclusiveness in computing education and careers; and (4) expand an online resource center to share research and successful practices worldwide. Applying methods grounded in knowledge management, collaboration, and social network theory and practice, this extension to the AccessComputing award will formalize earlier and new relationships into a multitier organizational structure of partners, collaborators, and affiliates. Outcomes for individuals with disabilities will be documented by tracking the progress of student participants as well as institutional enrollment and graduation data; and results will be compared to local, regional, and national data with respect to the academic and career success of people with disabilities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The University of Washington (UW) was funded (grant #CNS-1042260) by the National Science Foundation (NSF) to lead a comprehensive, multidisciplinary network of stakeholders with the goal of increasing the participation of people with disabilities successful in degree completion and careers in computing fields. The following summarizes outputs and outcomes from the AccessComputing Second Extension project.

Outputs and Outcomes for Students with Disabilities: During the project, 2,665 individuals with disabilities participated in college transition and bridge academies, workshops, presentations, an online mentoring community, internships, conference attendance, and/or other opportunities offered through AccessComputing many were conducted via minigrants to partner institutions.

Students interested in receiving support and ongoing engagement in the AccessComputing initiative joined the “AccessComputing Team.”  During the project period, 445 students with disabilities joined the AccessComputing Team. They received peer and mentor support within an e-mentoring community; secured internships; engaged in college and career transition events; received tutoring; attended conferences; and/or received advice from project staff and other participants regarding the acquisition of assistive technology and preparation for computing studies and careers.

A total of 419 (94%) of the 445 AccessComputing Team members were enrolled in postsecondary education during the project. Sixty-one participants pursued a two-year degree or a certificate. Of these, one-third were still attending at the time of data collection and 42 (67%) had graduated. Of those who had graduated, 27 (64%) transitioned into to a four-year program. Of the 340 enrolled in a four-year degree program, 196 (58%) graduated during the data collection period and 133 (39%) were still attending. Of the 196 who had graduated 42 (21%) transitioned into a graduate or professional program during the data collection period. Of the 104 who had enrolled in a graduate or professional program during the data collection period, 42 (40%) graduated from their program and 55 (53%) were still attending. 

One of the strategies employed was to provide diverse learning experiences and to support team members’ interest in computing is engagement in internships. A total of 185 students participated in 282 internships. During the data collection period 150 of the AccessComputing Team members secured employment, and nearly all of them (94%) fulltime and nearly all of them (91%) computer-related. 

Building Organizational Capacity. AccessComputing worked to create and support synergistic and lasting relationships among stakeholders to foster systemic changes toward inclusiveness in computing education and careers; to implement evidence-based practices to increase the number of individuals with disabilities progressing through critical junctures to computing careers; and to expand an online resource to share research and promising practices worldwide. Some of the most dramatic achievements of AccessComputing were seen in organizational capacity and alliance development. Project outputs and outcomes include:

Partner Engagement. AccessComputing engaged with 46 project partners and 208 collaborators. Partners regularly communicated in telephone conferences and online forums and led project activities within their organizations.

Minigrants. Minigrants were used to support activities that promoted the participation of students with disabilities in higher education and computing. AccessComputing awarded 37 minigrants to 26 individuals at 22 institutions. Funded activities had a direct impact on a total of 824 students with disabilities, 743 precollege students and 58 college students.  

Communities of Practice (CoP). A total of 566 individuals participated in six stakeholder forums to discuss issues and share resources related to the project goal. 

Training. Fifteen web-based trainings, reaching 2,226 individuals, some hosted by project partners and collaborators, were conducted during the project. Additionally, 2,564 individuals participated in 47 events at partner and collaborator sites and 9,214 individuals received training through 135 presentations at regional and national conferences and meetings.

Dissemination. AccessComputing created a website, 2 videos, and 17 publications. More than 2,100 copies of project materials were freely distributed. Additionally more than 6,605 individuals received project materials and/or engaged with project staff at regional and national conferences and meetings. Dissemination of project materials to computing faculty and departments, disability service offices, broadening participation projects, computer science teachers, and AccessComputing partners totaled 14,829 copies to more than 13,502 individuals and organizations. 

AccessComputing ensured long-term impact because it:

  • broadened the participation in computing of people with disabilities, including those who are also women, underrepresented minorities, post-911veterans, and/or economically disadvantaged;
  • built on existing associations and networks and created durable relationships among stakeholders in an integrated effort that enhanced the infrastructure for research and education to make them more accessible and welcoming for people with disabilities;
  • disseminated transformation research and practice to enhance understanding of disability and promote replication of promising practices: and
  • put into place structures that will sustain project impact after the project funding period has ended.

Transformational project outcomes benefit society by making computing opportunities available to more citizens and by enhancing computing fields with the talents and perspectives of people with disabilities. Project products are available on the project website at http://www.washington.edu/accesscomputing/.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2017
Modified by: Sheryl Burgstahler
